title: Aurora Australis over Concordia station
summary: The Aurora Australis, photographed over Concordia station in July 2025, during the ongoing solar activity maximum, the peak of the Sun's 11-year cycle.
detailed_news: Aurora Australis appears when charged particles from the Sun are guided by Earth’s magnetic field towards the polar regions. Concordia station, perched high on Antarctica’‘Dome C plateau, is one of the most remote research outposts on Earth. Each year, ESA sponsors a medical doctor to live and work at Concordia.

title: Lunar Environment Structural Test Rig
summary: The Lunar Environment Structural Test Rig simulates the intense cold of the lunar night, ranging from 40 Kelvin (K) to 125 K while maintaining a vacuum environment. This creates a tool by which scientists and engineers can test materials, electronics, and flight hardware for future Moon and Mars missions, characterizing their behaviors at these temperatures while also validating their ability to meet design requirements.
detailed_news: LESTR simulates the intense cold of the lunar night, ranging from 40 Kelvin (K) to 125 K. It uses a cryocooler to reject heat and bring the test section to any point desired by the test engineer. LESTR enables safe, accurate, and cost-effective testing of materials and hardware.

title: Rocket Report: Pivotal Starship test on tap, Firefly wants to be big in Japan
summary: Starship returns to the launch pad for the first time in three months.
detailed_news: SpaceX's Starship rocket will return to the launch pad for the first time in three months on Sunday. A Chinese methane-powered rocket failed on Friday after the carrier rocket experienced an "anomaly" The French government has granted Avio a 10-year license to carry out Vega rocket operations from the Guiana Space Centre. SpaceX launched its 100th Falcon 9 rocket of the year Monday morning. Students from Concordia University cheered and whistled as the Starsailor rocket lifted off on Cree territory on August 15. This was Canada's first space launch in more than 25 years, and the first to be achieved by a team of students, according to the university. SpaceX has not had a good run of things with the ambitious Starship vehicle this year. Three times, in January, March, and May, the vehicle took flight. Sources at SpaceX believe the upper stage issues can be resolved. But the acid test will only come on upcoming flights, beginning Sunday. Engineers recreated the diffuser failure on the ground during the investigation. They then redesigned the part to better direct pressurized gas into the main fuel tank. This will also "substantially decrease" strain on the Diffuser structure, SpaceX said. The Falcon 9 is scheduled to launch on August 22.

title: Hubble Observes Noteworthy Nearby Spiral Galaxy
summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image offers a new view of the nearby spiral galaxy NGC 2835, which lies 35 million light-years away in the constellation Hydra (the Water Snake). The galaxy’s spiral arms are dotted with young blue stars sweeping around an oval-shaped center where older stars reside. This image differs from previously released […]
detailed_news: NGC 2835 lies 35 million light-years away in the constellation Hydra (the Water Snake) The galaxy’s spiral arms are dotted with young blue stars sweeping around an oval-shaped center where older stars reside. This image differs from previously released images from Hubble and the NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 24 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg SFB
summary: The mission will include the 1,800th Starlink satellite launched in 2025. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 4E at Vandenberg Space Force Base at 10:02 a.m. PDT (1:02 p.m. EDT / 1702 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is planning to launch of its latest batch of Starlink V2 Mini satellites from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California on Friday. The Starlink 17-6 mission will add another 24 satellites to the low Earth orbit constellation. With a successful completion of this mission, SpaceX will have launched more than 1,800 of its Starlink satellites in 2025 alone.

title: SpaceX launches Space Force’s X-37B spaceplane to demo laser communications, quantum navigation
summary: The uncrewed spacecraft will operate in low Earth orbit for an unspecified amount of time. This is the eighth launch of an X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle since its first flight in 2010.
detailed_news: The X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle was launched Thursday night. It's the eighth mission for the program, which began operational flights in April 2010. There are two operational spaceplanes in the X- 37B fleet. The rocket's first stage will attempt to land on a SpaceX droneship. NASA, Boeing and Lockheed Martin argued that the United States shouldn't skip past the Moon in favor of Mars. The discussion came up during a panel at the SpaceCom conference concerning the Artemis 2 mission. A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket loaded with 10 Iridium Next communications satellite is awaiting a predawn launch Wednesday from Vandenberg Air Force Base.

title: X-37B Lifts Off on Eighth Mission
summary: The U.S. Space Force’s X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle lifted off from Kennedy Space Center just before midnight on its eighth flight, OTV-8. Looking like a small space shuttle, the spaceplane […]
detailed_news: The U.S. Space Force’s X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle lifted off from Kennedy Space Center just before midnight on its eighth flight, OTV-8. Looking like a small space shuttle, the spaceplane was nestled inside the fairing of a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. The USSF released a pre-launch photo and shared a few nuggets about some of the experiments aboard, but little is known about what these X- 37B missions do. Boeing built two X-37Bs. USSF didn’t specify which is being used for this mission. Some question whether it may be a space weapon of some kind. Secure World Foundation tracks global counterspace capabilities and concludes that’s not likely.

title: NASA’s SpaceX 33rd Commercial Resupply Mission Overview
summary: NASA and SpaceX are targeting no earlier than 2:45 a.m. EDT on Sunday, Aug. 24, for the next launch to deliver scientific investigations, supplies, and equipment to the International Space Station.
detailed_news: The SpaceX Dragon spacecraft will arrive at the space station at approximately 7:30 a.m. on Monday, Aug. 25. NASA astronauts Mike Fincke and Jonny Kim will monitor the spacecraft’s arrival. It will stay docked to the orbiting laboratory for about four months before splashing down. Reboost Kit – This kit will perform a reboost demonstration of the station to maintain its current altitude. Separator Orbital Unit – The unit draws air and condensate mixture from a condensing heat exchanger. Reducer Cylinder Assembly & Emergency Portable Breathing Apparatus – Together, this hardware provides 15 minutes of oxygen to a crew member in case of an emergency. Oxygen Generation Assembly Pump converts potable water from the water recovery system into oxygen and hydrogen. The oxygen is sent to the crew cabin, and the hydrogen is either vented or used to produce more water. The Rate Gyro Enclosure Assembly determines the space station’s rate of angular motion.

title: To See the World in a Grain of Sand: Investigating Megaripples at ‘Kerrlaguna’
summary: Written by Athanasios Klidaras, Ph.D. candidate at Purdue University On Mars, the past is written in stone — but the present is written in sand. Last week, Perseverance explored inactive megaripples to learn more about the wind-driven processes that are reshaping the Martian landscape every day.  After wrapping up its investigation at the contact between […]
detailed_news: Perseverance explored inactive megaripples to learn more about the wind-driven processes that are reshaping the Martian landscape every day. It is hoped that this investigation at “Kerrlaguna’ can provide a practice run for a more comprehensive campaign located at a more extensive field of larger bedforms at ‘Lac de Charmes’

title: NASA Astronauts to Answer Questions from Students in Ohio
summary: NASA astronauts Michael Fincke and Zena Cardman will connect with students in Ohio as they answer prerecorded science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) questions aboard the International Space Station. The Earth-to-space call will begin at 10:15 a.m. EDT on Wednesday, Aug. 27, and will stream live on the agency’s Learn With NASA YouTube channel. Media […]
detailed_news: Astronauts Michael Fincke and Zena Cardman will answer prerecorded science, technology, engineering, and mathematics questions. The Earth-to-space call will begin at 10:15 a.m. EDT on Wednesday, Aug. 27. Media interested in covering the event must RSVP by 5 p.m., Monday, August 25.

title: NASA’s Artemis II Lunar Science Operations to Inform Future Missions
summary: While the Artemis II crew will be the first humans to test NASA’s Orion spacecraft in space, they will also conduct science investigations that will inform future deep space missions, including a lunar science investigation as Orion flies about 4,000 to 6,000 miles from the Moon’s surface.
detailed_news: Artemis II crew will be the first humans to test NASA’s Orion spacecraft in space. Crew will analyze and photograph geologic features on the surface. Astronauts will practice describing nuances in shapes, textures, and colors of surface features. Artemis III astronauts will investigate the land forms, rocks, and other features around their landing site.  Artemis II will conduct experiments on the lunar surface. This data could inform long-term lunar exploration and future human missions to Mars. These experiments will be managed through the Payload Mission Operations Directorate at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center, in Huntsville, Alabama. For more information on Artemis II, visit: www.nasa.gov/mission/artemis-ii.

title: Cities by the Bay
summary: NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers took this photo of California’s San Francisco Bay Area surrounded by the cities of San Francisco, Oakland, and San Jose, and their suburbs on Aug. 3, 2025. At the time, the International Space Station orbited 260 miles above the Golden State. The International Space Station serves as a unique platform for […]
detailed_news: NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers took this photo of California’s San Francisco Bay Area surrounded by the cities of San Francisco, Oakland, and San Jose. At the time, the International Space Station orbited 260 miles above the Golden State. The space station serves as a unique platform for observing Earth with both hands-on and automated equipment.

title: Close-Up Views of NASA’s DART Impact to Inform Planetary Defense
summary: On Sept. 11, 2022, engineers at a flight control center in Turin, Italy, sent a radio signal into deep space. Its destination was NASA’s DART (Double Asteroid Redirection Test) spacecraft flying toward an asteroid more than 5 million miles away. The message prompted the spacecraft to execute a series of pre-programmed commands that caused a small, […]
detailed_news: NASA's DART spacecraft collided with near-Earth asteroid Dimorphos in 2022. A shoebox-sized satellite called LICIACube flew past the asteroid to snap a series of photos. The images provided the only on-site observations of the world's first demonstration of an asteroid deflection. The innermost parts of the plume were so thick with debris that they were completely opaque. Scientists used models to estimate the number of particles that were hidden from view. Data from other rubble-pile asteroids, including pieces of Bennu delivered to Earth in 2023 by NASA’s OSIRIS-REx spacecraft, helped refine the estimate.

title: NASA Invites Media to Joint Launch of Sun, Space Weather Missions
summary: Media accreditation is open for the launch of three observatories that will study the Sun and enhance the ability to make accurate space weather forecasts, helping protect technology systems that affect life on Earth. NASA is targeting no earlier than Tuesday, Sept. 23, for the launch of the agency’s IMAP (Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe), […]
detailed_news: NASA is targeting no earlier than Tuesday, Sept. 23, for the launch of the agency’s IMAP ( Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe ) IMAP will use 10 science instruments to study and map the heliosphere, a vast magnetic bubble surrounding the Sun. The Carruthers Geocorona Observatory is a small satellite set to study the exosphere, the outermost part of Earth's atmosphere. IMAP is the fifth mission in NASA’s Solar Terrestrial Probes program portfolio. Princeton University professor David McComas leads the IMAP mission with an international team of 25 partner institutions. The Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory in Laurel, Maryland, built the spacecraft and operates the mission.

title: France Grants Avio 10-Year Licence to Launch from Guiana Space Centre
summary:
The French government has granted Italian launch services provider Avio a ten-year licence to carry out Vega rocket operations from the Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana. During the 2023 Space Summit in Seville, European Space Agency Member States approved Italy’s petition to allow Avio to market and manage Vega rocket launches independently of Arianespace, […]
The post France Grants Avio 10-Year Licence to Launch from Guiana Space Centre appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The French government has granted Avio a ten-year licence to carry out Vega rocket operations from the Guiana Space Centre in French Guiana. During the 2023 Space Summit in Seville, European Space Agency Member States approved Italy’s petition to allow Avio to market and manage Vega rocket launches. The company will formally take over the operation of the rocket with the launch of Vega C flight VV30, slated for later this year.

title: X-37B set to launch on USSF-36 mission aboard Falcon 9
summary:
The U.S. Department of Defense’s reusable X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle (OTV) is about to make…
The post X-37B set to launch on USSF-36 mission aboard Falcon 9 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The U.S. Department of Defense’s reusable X-37B Orbital Test Vehicle (OTV) is about to make its eighth overall flight into orbit. Vehicle 1 is scheduled to launch atop a SpaceX Falcon 9 from the Kennedy Space Center on Thursday, August 21, at 11:50 PM EDT (03:50 UTC on Friday, Aug. 22) The launch window is just under four hours long and lasts until 3:40 AM EDT (07:40 UTC) on Friday morning. After liftoff, Falcon 9 will follow a northeast trajectory to loft the OTV into a low-Earth orbit, possibly a circular orbit at 500 km altitude inclined 49.5 degrees to the equator. OTV-8 will demonstrate laser communications using proliferated low-Earth orbit (LEO) communications satellite networks. Laser communications can carry higher data bandwidth due to the shorter wavelength of infrared light versus radio waves. The quantum inertial sensor experiment is also an effort to increase resiliency in military space systems. The X-37B OTV is a spaceflight-capable spacecraft. It is nearly nine meters long and features a 4.5 m wingspan. The spaceplane’s capacity to fly experiments was increased when a non-reusable service module for use in space was added to the design.

title: SpaceX has built the machine to build the machine. But what about the machine?
summary: SpaceX has built an impressive production site in Texas. Will Starship success follow?
detailed_news: SpaceX has built an impressive production site in Texas. The factory measures about 1 million square feet. This is two times as large as SpaceX's main Falcon 9 factory in Hawthorne, California. The ultimate goal of this factory is to build one Starship rocket a day. SpaceX has not had a good run of things with the ambitious Starship vehicle this year. Three times, in January, March, and May, the vehicle took flight. The vehicle's tenth test flight is scheduled to take place no earlier than August 24. Success with Starship would solve a lot of problems for SpaceX. SpaceX's Starship program has been so disappointing this year. There will be a lot of learning, and almost certainly some failures, as SpaceX works through these technical milestones. If it continues to have teething pains, though, that makes it easier for Congress to continue funding NASA's expensive rocket and spacecraft, as it would prefer to do. Musk is highly critical of Artemis, saying NASA should focus on Mars. Both the Moon and Mars versions of Starship require the vehicle to reach orbit and successfully refuel. If Artemis is not a priority for Musk, how can it be for SpaceX? This all creates a tremendous amount of uncertainty ahead of Sunday's Starship launch.

title: NASA Selecting New Astronauts, Gearing Up for Artemis II
summary: In four weeks, NASA will introduce a new class of astronauts as it begins gearing up for the launch of Artemis II, the first time humans will travel around the […]
detailed_news: NASA will introduce a new class of astronauts as it begins gearing up for the launch of Artemis II, the first time humans will travel around the Moon since the Apollo era. Artemis II is a test flight that will not attempt even to orbit the Moon, much less land. The four-person American-Canadian crew will fly a free-return trajectory taking them past the Moon and back to Earth. Cruz posted a video of the JSC visit and wrote that he is “making sure we have the tools we need to maintain American dominance in space,” but provided no details about the fate of the $10 billion. He and Babin wrote to Duffy on August 5 asking for details on when and how it will be spent. NASA laid out an architecture for routine flights beyond that, including assembling a lunar Gateway space station. The Trump Administration wants to kill not only Gateway, but SLS and Orion after Artemis III and replace them with commercial alternatives. Congress disagrees, pointing out commercial alternatives don’t exist yet.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4636-4637: Up Against a Wall
summary: Written by Michelle Minitti, MAHLI Deputy Principal Investigator, Framework Earth planning date: Wednesday, Aug. 20, 2025 What does a good rover do when her back is up against a wall? Fight for science! Curiosity indeed fought the good fight at “Río Frío,” the wall of one of the many ridges cutting through the boxwork terrain […]
detailed_news: The observations along the wall today provide insight into the internal structure and chemistry of the ridges. The structural story will be told by the large Mastcam mosaics we planned, covering the ridge from base to top. The mosaic target, “Jardín de las Delicias,” will surely yield a surfeit of Martian delights.

title: Firefly Looks to Japan’s Hokkaido Spaceport for First Asia Launch Site; Signs Feasibility Study MOU
summary: Firefly Looks to Japan’s Hokkaido Spaceport for First Asia Launch Site; Signs Feasibility Study MOU
detailed_news: The agreement will study the feasibility of launching Firefly’s small-lift Alpha rocket from the growing commercial spaceport in Taiki Town, Japan. For Firefly, the agreement marks a potential expansion into Asia and adds flexibility for customers in the region. The news comes as Firefly works to return Alpha to flight following a failure earlier this year. The timing of any Firefly launches from Hokkaido remains uncertain. A company spokesperson confirmed that the schedule will depend on the results of the feasibility study under the newly signed MOU. If successful, the agreement would mark a significant milestone for both Firefly and SPACE COTAN: Firefly would secure access to Asia’s rapidly growing satellite market.

title: X-ray and Radio go ‘Hand in Hand’ in New Image
summary: In 2009, NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory released a captivating image: a pulsar and its surrounding nebula that is shaped like a hand. Since then, astronomers have used Chandra and other telescopes to continue to observe this object. Now, new radio data from the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA), has been combined with Chandra’s X-ray data […]
detailed_news: Pulsar B1509-58 is a rapidly spinning neutron star that is only about 12 miles in diameter. This tiny object is responsible for producing an intricate nebula that spans over 150 light-years, or about 900 trillion miles. The nebula, which is produced by energetic particles, resembles a human hand with a palm and extended fingers pointing to the upper right in X-rays.  composite image of a nebula and pulsar that strongly resembles a cosmic hand reaching for a neon red cloud. Breaks in the cloud reveal interwoven strands of gold resembling spiderwebs, or a latticework substructure. The pulsar, a rapidly spinning neutron star only 12 miles in diameter, is far too small to be seen in this image, which represents a region of space over 150 light-years across.

title: NASA to Announce New Astronaut Class, Preview Artemis II Moon Mission

detailed_news: NASA is opening media accreditation for multi-day events to introduce America’s newest astronaut class. The Artemis II crewed test flight around the Moon will take place in September. Media who wish to participate in person must contact the NASA Johnson newsroom at 281-483-5111 or jsccommu@mail.nasa.gov. For more information on NASA's Human Spaceflight Program, please visit: http://humansinspace.gov.

title: NASA: Ceres May Have Had Long-Standing Energy to Fuel Habitability
summary: The dwarf planet is cold now, but new research paints a picture of Ceres hosting a deep, long-lived energy source that may have maintained habitable conditions in the past. New NASA research has found that Ceres may have had a lasting source of chemical energy: the right types of molecules needed to fuel some microbial […]
detailed_news: Dwarf planet Ceres may have had a long-lived source of chemical energy. The right molecules needed to fuel some microbial metabolisms. No evidence that microorganisms ever existed on Ceres. Findings support theories that this intriguing dwarf planet may have once had conditions suitable to support single-celled lifeforms. Dawn was a project of the directorate’s Discovery Program. Northrop Grumman in Dulles, Virginia, designed and built the spacecraft. German Aerospace Center, Max Planck Institute for Solar System Research, Italian Space Agency and Italian National Astrophysical Institute were international partners on the mission team.

title: Russia launches Bion-M No.2 research satellite
summary:
Russia launched the Bion-M No.2 satellite at 17:13 UTC on Wednesday, Aug. 20, aboard a…
The post Russia launches Bion-M No.2 research satellite appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Russia launched the Bion-M No.2 satellite at 17:13 UTC on Wednesday, Aug. 20, aboard a Soyuz-2-1b rocket from Site 31/6 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome. This biomedical satellite is a continuation of a Soviet and later Russian scientific program, which started with the launch of Bion 1 back in 1973. Bion program uses spacecraft that are based on the Zenit series of reconnaissance satellites, sharing the same basic design. Bion-M № 2 is scheduled to land on the steppe in the Orenburg region on September 19. The mice were bred specifically for this spaceflight. The NRF2 gene, which regulates the detoxification and antioxidant protection system, is the focus of this research. Bion-M No.2 mission will study the germination of seeds, study the effects of space conditions on the plants. Various microorganisms are also flying on board the satellite: anaerobic, spore-forming microorganisms and extremophiles. A place on board has been found for two experiments designed by school students. The mission comes over 12 years after the previous mission, which returned to Earth in May 2013.

title: Viking 1 Begins Journey to Mars
summary: A Titan-Centaur rocket carrying the Viking 1 spacecraft launches from Complex 41 at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on Aug. 20, 1975. Viking 1 touched down on the red planet on July 20, 1976, becoming the first truly successful landing on Mars. Viking 1 was the first of a pair of complex deep space probes […]
detailed_news: Viking 1 touched down on the red planet on July 20, 1976, becoming the first truly successful landing on Mars. Viking 1 was the first of a pair of complex deep space probes that were designed to reach Mars. NASA’s exploration of Mars continues, with rovers exploring the surface and spacecraft studying from orbit.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch X-37B military spaceplane on Falcon 9 rocket from the Kennedy Space Center
summary: This will be the eighth flight of the X-37B and the third time that it will launched by SpaceX. The Falcon 9 rocket is scheduled to liftoff from Launch Complex 39A at 11:50 p.m. EDT (0350 UTC).
detailed_news: The U.S. Space Force and SpaceX are preparing to launch the Boeing-built X-37B spaceplane on its eighth mission shortly before midnight on Thursday. The winged spacecraft, flying under the mission names USSF-36 and Orbital Test Vehicle 8 (OTV-8), will launch atop a Falcon 9 rocket from pad 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center at 11:50 p.m. EDT (0350 UTC) Meteorologists with the 45th Weather Squadron forecast a 65 percent chance for favorable conditions for liftoff. The OTV-8 flight will also feature what the Space Force calls “the world’s highest performing quantum inertial sensor ever used in space” It will demonstrate navigational capabilities without the use of GPS by instead “detecting rotation and acceleration of atoms”

title: Firefly Aerospace explores launching its Alpha rocket from Japan
summary: If the company moves forward with this possibility, it would present Firefly with a third launch site for its Alpha rockets.
detailed_news: Hokkaido Spaceport has room for two launch complexes designed to support the launches of small, orbital-class rockets. All six of Firefly Aerospace’s Alpha rocket launches so far took off from Space Launch Complex 2 at Vandenberg Space Force Base in California. Rocket Lab has launched the vast majority of its more than 60 Electron rockets from Mahia, New Zealand.  Firefly Aerospace launched its Alpha rocket Friday after a launch attempt on Wednesday was scrubbed by bad weather. The infrastructure expansion in Briggs, Texas, boosts the company’s manufacturing space from 92,000 to 207,000 square feet. Liftoff with a payload for Lockheed Martin occurred at 9:32 a.m. PST.

title: Steve Platnick Steps Down from NASA After 34 Years of Service
summary: Dr. Steven “Steve” Platnick took the NASA agency Deferred Resignation Program (DRP). His last work day was August 8, 2025. Steve spent more than three decades at, or associated with, NASA. While he began his civil servant career at the NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) in 2002, his Goddard association went back to 1993, […]
detailed_news: Dr. Steven “Steve” Platnick took the NASA Deferred Resignation Program (DRP) His last work day was August 8, 2025. Steve played an integral role in the sustainability and advancement of NASA’s Earth Observing System platforms and data. Steve has participated in numerous major airborne field campaigns over his career. His key ER-2 flight scientist and/or science team management roles included the Monterey Area Ship Track experiment (MAST, 1994) Steve has been a champion of continuing to retain a historical record of NASA science team meetings. He has received numerous honors, including the Goddard William Nordberg Memorial Award for Earth Science in 2023.

title: NASA, IBM’s ‘Hot’ New AI Model Unlocks Secrets of Sun
summary: Editor’s Note: This article was updated Aug. 20, 2025, to correct the number of years of training data used and the model accuracy. The original article said the model was trained on 14 years of Solar Dynamics Observatory data and surpassed existing benchmarks by 15%; the model was actually trained on 9 years of data and […]
detailed_news: Surya uses advances in AI to analyze vast amounts of solar data. The model can be used to provide early warnings to satellite operators. It also helps scientists predict how the Sun’s ultraviolet output affects Earth's upper atmosphere. Preliminary results show Surya is making strides in solar flare forecasting. Surya is designed to study the Sun, but its architecture and methodology are adaptable across scientific domains. The project lays the foundational infrastructure for similar AI efforts in diverse domains. Both the model and training datasets are freely available online to researchers, educators, and students worldwide. NASA's commitment to open science fuels groundbreaking research while maximizing transparency, innovation, and collaboration. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. The agency is based in Washington, D.C. and has offices around the world.

title: Iberian wildfires seen from space
summary: Southern Europe is once again in the grip of extreme summer heat. Soaring temperatures and bone-dry land have fuelled widespread wildfires, with the Iberian Peninsula among the regions hardest hit. Flames continue to sweep across parched landscapes, as these images show.
detailed_news: Soaring temperatures and bone-dry land have fuelled widespread wildfires, with the Iberian Peninsula among the regions hardest hit. From orbit, Earth-observing satellites offer a unique way of tracking the spread of fires and supporting emergency crews battling the blazes on the ground. The images featured here reveal the scale of the crisis, with dense smoke plumes from several fires stretching across large areas of northwest Spain and northern Portugal. The Climate Change Initiative is designed to generate consistent, long-term global datasets of Essential Climate Variables that provide robust evidence of our changing climate. These projects are helping to improve predictions, guide adaptation strategies, and strengthen our collective response to a warming world. You can only like this page once.

title: UK Space Agency to Lose Limited Autonomy to Government Streamlining
summary:
The UK Space Agency has announced that from April 2026 it will be absorbed into the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology, losing its executive agency status. In its 20 August announcement, the UK Space Agency stated that the restructuring, which is part of broader governmental “streamlining”, would remove duplication, reduce bureaucracy, and put “public […]
The post UK Space Agency to Lose Limited Autonomy to Government Streamlining appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The UK Space Agency has announced that from April 2026 it will be absorbed into the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology. In 2010, the country began the process of establishing its own centralized space agency set up as an executive agency. As a DSIT executive agency, the UKSA currently operates with limited managerial independence in delivering government space policy. title: UK Government Abolishes Independent UK Space Agency; Will Merge Into DSIT by 2026
summary: UK Government Abolishes Independent UK Space Agency; Will Merge Into DSIT by 2026
detailed_news: The UK Space Agency will cease to exist as an independent body by April 2026. The agency will be absorbed into the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology (DSIT) Officials said the change would reduce duplication, improve efficiency, and ensure stronger ministerial oversight. Supporters of the agency expressed concern that the merger could slow innovation and reduce agility.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4634-4635: A Waiting Game
summary: Written by Lucy Thompson, Planetary Scientist and APXS Team Member, University of New Brunswick, Canada Earth Planning Date: Monday, Aug. 18, 2025 The downlink data from our weekend activities arrived on Earth as we started planning this morning. As the APXS payload uplink and downlink lead, I assess the downlink data to ensure that our […]
detailed_news: Downlink data from our weekend activities arrived on Earth as we started planning this morning. The drive executed as planned and we are on stable ground, which will enable us to unstow the arm for contact science with APXS and MAHLI. We selected a representative bedrock patch (“Gil”) that was large enough and smooth enough to brush for dust removal. ChemCam will also analyze this target with LIBS, and Mastcam will capture a documentation image.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4631-4633: Radiant Ridge Revolution
summary: Written by Remington Free, Operations Systems Engineer at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory Earth planning date: Friday, Aug. 15, 2025 Today we uplinked a three-sol weekend plan with lots of exciting activities — to support both the science and engineering teams!  While usually our science activities take front and center stage, we often also do engineering […]
detailed_news: On Sol 4631, we planned a maintenance activity of our Battery Control Boards (BCBs) This maintenance is done periodically to correct for any time drift on the BCBs, so we get as accurate of data as possible. After completing our engineering activities, we started off with some remote science; this included Mastcam imaging and ChemCam measurements of several interesting targets. On Sol 4633, we continued with more science imaging, including a horizon movie using Navcam and a dust-devil movie, before proceeding into our drive.

title: Sun at the Center: Teacher Ambassadors Bring Heliophysics to Classrooms Nationwide
summary: For the fourth year in a row, the American Association of Physics Teachers, a collaborator on the NASA Heliophysics Education Activation Team (HEAT), selected eight new educators to serve as ambassadors for heliophysics education. Meeting in Boulder, CO, from July 14-17, 2025, these teachers met to work through AAPT’s lessons that bring physics content to […]
detailed_news: The American Association of Physics Teachers selected eight new educators to serve as ambassadors for heliophysics education. The Ambassador program began in 2022 as an effort to identify highly-motivated secondary and tertiary educators. Since the program began, 32 Ambassadors have been identified and participated in the multi-day professional learning experience.

title: NASA’s X-59 Nears First Flight
summary: As we honor the legacy of aviation pioneers this National Aviation Day, NASA’s X-59 is preparing to push the boundaries of what’s possible in air travel. The quiet supersonic aircraft’s historic first flight is on the horizon, with final ground tests about to begin. Following completion of low-speed taxi tests in July 2025 in Palmdale, […]
detailed_news: The quiet supersonic aircraft’s historic first flight is on the horizon. The X-59 will reach speeds of approximately 240 mph at an altitude of about 12,000 feet. The flight data will help inform U.S. and international regulators as they consider new noise standards.

title: What is BioNutrients?
summary: A series of biology experiments, called BioNutrients, is testing ways to use microorganisms to produce nutrients – off Earth and on demand – that will be critical for human health in space. Editor’s note: This article was updated on Aug. 19, 2025, to clarify which BioNutrients experiments in the series are completed and adds new […]
detailed_news: NASA is developing technologies to biomanufacture valuable products on-demand. Long-duration human exploration missions to the Moon and Mars will require minimizing the amounts of supplies launched. Planning new ways to supply food for a multi-year mission on the Moon or Mars may require making food and nutrients in space. The BioNutrients-3 investigation is planned to launch to the space station in August 2025 aboard NASA’s SpaceX CRS-33 mission. It aims to develop a platform biomanufacturing technology that demonstrates microbial production of targeted nutrients for long-duration space missions. The concept is similar to making familiar fermented foods, such as how milk – transformed by bacteria – becomes yogurt. BioNutrients-3 includes the same commercial yogurt and kefir starters used in BioNutrient-2 and adds yeast strains that have been bioengineered to produce multiple nutrients in a single bag. The growth substrate – the ingredients needed to sustain the microorganisms as they grow, including a color-changing indicator of the level of acidity in the samples – is fully edible.

title: NASA’s Psyche Captures Images of Earth, Moon
summary: Headed for a metal-rich asteroid of the same name, the Psyche spacecraft successfully calibrated its cameras by looking homeward. On schedule for its 2029 arrival at the asteroid Psyche, NASA’s Psyche spacecraft recently looked back toward home and captured images of Earth and our Moon from about 180 million miles (290 million kilometers) away. The […]
detailed_news: NASA's Psyche spacecraft recently looked back toward home and captured images of Earth and our Moon from about 180 million miles (290 million kilometers) away. The images were obtained during one of the mission team’s periodic checkouts of the spacecraft's science instruments. Psyche is headed for a metal-rich asteroid of the same name and is scheduled to arrive in 2029. Psyche is the 14th mission selected as part of NASA’s Discovery Program. Moonquakes pose little risk to astronauts during a mission lasting just a few days. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery.

title: Moonlight and Our Atmosphere
summary: The Moon’s light is refracted by Earth’s atmosphere in this April 13, 2025, photograph from the International Space Station as it orbited into a sunset 264 miles above the border between Bolivia and Brazil in South America. Understanding the Moon helps us understand other planets, how they have evolved and the processes which have shaped […]
detailed_news: Understanding the Moon helps us understand other planets, how they have evolved and the processes which have shaped their surfaces. By using the Moon as our closest testing ground for robotics and instrument systems, we can further human exploration to not only the Moon, but the rest of the solar system. Through Artemis missions, NASA will send astronauts to explore the Moon for scientific discovery and economic benefits.

title: National Aviation Day: Celebrating NASA’s Heritage While Charting Our Future
summary: As we observe National Aviation Day Tuesday – a tribute to Orville Wright’s birthday – let’s reflect on both America’s and NASA’s aviation heritage and share how we are pushing the boundaries of flight for the nation’s future. Modern NASA grew from the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA), an agency created by Congress in […]
detailed_news: NASA grew from the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA) NACA was created by Congress in 1915 to advance U.S. aviation. NASA’s commitment to aviation innovation did not stop with early experimental high-speed aircraft. Later this year, NASA Test Pilot Nils Larson will usher in a new era of quiet supersonic flight. Todd Ericson: I am continually inspired by the ingenuity of our past and the promise of our future. He says the pursuit of quiet supersonic aircraft, hypersonic technologies, and revitalized general aviation will keep the U.S. aviation industry strong and sustainable.

title: Starbase Pad 2: Design Advancements from Pad 1
summary:
SpaceX’s Starbase facility in Boca Chica, Texas, continues to evolve as the company pushes the…
The post Starbase Pad 2: Design Advancements from Pad 1 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Pad 2 launch tower base features a stainless steel framework filled with concrete, a significant departure from Pad A’s concrete base with stainless steel cladding. The housing at the rear of the Pad 2 tower base is substantially larger and more robust. Pad 2 chopsticks are approximately 10 metres shorter than Pad 1's; this is expected to improve responsiveness during catch attempts. The Pad 2 carriage incorporates a redesigned skate system, differing from the Pad 1 configuration. The pistons used for moving these chopsticks laterally are significantly simplified compared to those on Pad 1. The rigging layout on the Pad 2 tower differs from Pad 1’s regarding the placement of the drawworks and the dead spool & deadline anchor. The Pad 2 launch mount is equipped with two Booster Quick Disconnects (BQDs), as opposed to Pad 1’s single BQD. These two BQDs appear to be separated for liquid oxygen and liquid methane supply. The top surface of the launch mount incorporates a water-cooled steel plate, similar to the one implemented under Pad 1 since Flight 2. Pad 2 will only share storage tanks with Pad 1. The layout of the Pad 2 end of the tank farm is entirely different from Pad 1’s, likely based on extensive lessons learned from all prior Starship ground tests and launches. Pad 2 will have its dedicated liquid oxygen and liquid methane pumps and subcoolers, amongst other items of GSE-related hardware. Starbase Pad 2 is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2025. It will be the second Starbase Pad to be built in the U.S. The project is funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASASpaceflight.com)

title: NASA-funded Compact Radar Drives Big Changes in Airborne and Suborbital Radar Capabilities
summary: A collaboration between NASA and the small business Aloft Sensing produced a new compact radar system that will enable researchers to leverage High Altitude Long Endurance (HALE) platforms to observe dynamic Earth systems. This new radar is small, provides highly sensitive measurements, and doesn’t require GPS for positioning; eventually, it could be used on vehicles […]
detailed_news: New radar is small, provides highly sensitive measurements, and doesn’t require GPS for positioning. Eventually, it could be used on vehicles in space. “It’s a level of sensitivity that has eluded traditional radar sensors, without making them bulky and expensive,” said Lauren Wye, CEO of Aloft Sensing. HALE InSAR can be used to navigate without GPS in austere environments where reliable GPS signals may be unavailable. The Aloft Sensing team recently achieved several key milestones, validating their instrument aboard an airship at 65,000 feet as well as small stratospheric balloons. The Snapshot Wisconsin project recently collected their 100 millionth trail camera photo.

title: Polish Consortium Selects Payloads for State-Sponsored Suborbital Rocket Launch
summary:
On 19 August, Poland’s Łukasiewicz Research Network’s Institute of Aviation revealed the four payloads that were selected to fly aboard a suborbital rocket under a Polish Space Agency–funded launch service. In April, the Polish Space Agency issued a call for proposals under its “Development of Launch Technology and Demonstration of Launch Capability on Polish Suborbital […]
The post Polish Consortium Selects Payloads for State-Sponsored Suborbital Rocket Launch appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: The Polish Space Agency issued a call for proposals for a suborbital rocket test flight in April. In late July, the Polish Institute of Aviation invited proposals for potential payloads. The application process for this call closed on 11 August. On 19 August, Łukasiewicz ILOT announced that it had received 23 proposals and had selected four. The launch carrying the four payloads is expected to take place in October.

title: NASA Invites You to Celebrate National Aviation Day 2025
summary: The first “A” in NASA stands for Aeronautics – so naturally that means today, Aug. 19, National Aviation Day, is one of our favorite days all year! National Aviation Day was first proclaimed in 1939 by President Franklin Roosevelt to celebrate the birthday of aviation pioneer Orville Wright, who, with his brother Wilbur, in 1903, […]
detailed_news: National Aviation Day was first proclaimed in 1939 by President Franklin Roosevelt. Explore your local science center for exhibits about aviation and how an airplane flies. Grab some LEGO bricks and build the airplane of your dreams. Or make it easy on yourself, fold a paper airplane and shoot it across the room. NASA is working to transform air transportation to meet the future needs of the global aviation community. See how many different types of airplanes you can count or identify. Don’t hesitate to ask your librarian for help. Check out the NASA e-books you can download and own for free.

title: Where the Wild Things Are: Wildlife Management with Johnson’s Matt Strausser
summary: If you asked someone what they expected to see during a visit to NASA’s Johnson Space Center, they would probably list things like astronauts, engineers, and maybe a spacecraft or two. It might be a surprise to learn you can also spy hundreds of species of animals – from geckos and snakes to white-tailed deer […]
detailed_news: Matt Strausser is Johnson Space Center's senior biologist for wildlife management. He works to reduce the negative impacts animals can have on Johnson’s operations. Strausser also works to engage project and facility managers and provide recommendations on how to prevent or reduce the impact of wildlife problems onsite. Strausser says accomplishing the goals of the agency’s Artemis campaign will require a tremendous amount of specialized support infrastructure. “Building a wildlife and natural resource program from the ground up and bringing all of these once-disconnected and diverse professionals together to effectively address problems – that is the achievement I take the most pride in,” he said.

title: NASA Sets Coverage for SpaceX 33rd Station Resupply Launch, Arrival
summary: NASA and SpaceX are targeting 2:45 a.m. EDT, Sunday, Aug. 24, for the next launch to deliver science investigations, supplies, and equipment to the International Space Station. This is the 33rd SpaceX commercial resupply services mission to the orbital laboratory for NASA. Filled with more than 5,000 pounds of supplies, a SpaceX Dragon spacecraft on […]
detailed_news: This is the 33rd SpaceX commercial resupply services mission to the orbital laboratory for NASA. Filled with more than 5,000 pounds of supplies, a SpaceX Dragon spacecraft on a Falcon 9 rocket will lift off from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida. Dragon will dock autonomously about 7:30 a.m. on Monday, Aug. 25, to the forward port of the space station’s Harmony module. Let people know you’re watching the mission on X, Facebook, and Instagram by following and tagging these accounts. NASA’s virtual guest program for this mission also includes curated launch resources, notifications about related opportunities or changes, and a stamp for the NASA virtual guest passport following launch.

title: Station Nation: Meet Tess Caswell, Extravehicular Activity Flight Controller and Lead Capsule Communicator
summary: Tess Caswell supports the International Space Station from NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston as a capsule communicator, or capcom, as well as through the Extravehicular Activity Office. She is currently on rotation as the Artemis lead capcom, helping to develop training and processes for the Artemis campaign by leveraging her experience supporting the space […]
detailed_news: Tess Caswell supports the International Space Station from NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. She is currently on rotation as the Artemis lead capcom, helping to develop training and processes for the Artemis campaign. Caswell: I like to encourage young people to think about what part of space travel inspires them. Tess Caswell is an Extravehicular Activity Flight Controller and Lead Capsule Communicator. The space station brings people together in a common mission that benefits all of us. If you could have dinner with any astronaut, past or present, who would it be? Sally Ride, definitely.

title: After recent tests, China appears likely to beat the United States back to the Moon
summary: An expert explains why this will be enormously bad for the United States.
detailed_news: Chinese space program has reported some significant milestones in developing its program to land astronauts on the lunar surface by 2030. On August 6, the China Manned Space Agency successfully tested a high-fidelity mockup of its 26-ton "Lanyue" lunar lander. This work suggests that China is on course to land on the Moon before the end of this decade. Cheng: It seems quite likely that the Chinese will land on the Moon before NASA can return to the Moon. Cheng: If China regularly dispatches lunar missions, then it will rightfully be able to argue that Chinese should be the language of lunar/cis-lunar space traffic management. The Chinese are stable, systematic. They pursue a given goal (e.g., human spaceflight, a space station) over decades, with persistence and programmatic stability. So I expect that the Chinese will put a Chinese person on the Moon by 2030 and follow that with additional crewed and unmanned facilities. This will be supported by a built-out infrastructure of lunar PNT/comms.
